Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Adverse Event Reporting in Pediatric Heart Network Surgical Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized to either a standard adverse event reporting system (period 1) or a system focusing on serious adverse event reporting for six sentinel events (period 2).

Participants.evidence: The trial was conducted in a multicenter setting with infants eligible for Norwood surgery.

Intervention.evidence: comparing systemic–pulmonary artery shunt versus right ventricle–pulmonary artery conduit in infants with hypoplastic left heart syndrome.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate a novel adverse event reporting strategy in a randomized surgical trial.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of serious adverse events from randomization to hospital discharge after stage II surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 infants were randomized, 100 to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In period 2, the rate of serious adverse events requiring expedited reporting decreased significantly (0.42 vs 0.14/subject/month; P < .001).

Harms.evidence: Subjects with a serious adverse event in period 2 had higher rates of death and cardiac transplantation.
